question: In an activity-driven temporal network with 1000 nodes, where each node activates with a probability of alpha=0.1 and forms m=2 transient connections upon activation, how does the temporal structure of the network influence the spread of an infectious disease modeled using the SIR model with a basic reproduction number R0 = 3, compared to its corresponding time-aggregated static network in which edge weights represent the frequency of interactions over time?
next_plan: Now that the literature and online search establish the theoretical differences between the dynamics of epidemic spreading on activity-driven temporal networks and their time-aggregated static counterparts, the next critical step is modeling. I will now: (1) Construct both the activity-driven temporal and its corresponding aggregated static weighted network for N=1000 nodes, (2) Carefully set up the SIR model with R_0=3 and map infection/recovery rates accordingly, (3) Run detailed simulations over both types of networks, and (4) Quantitatively compare the epidemic dynamics—particularly the epidemic threshold, final size, speed of spread, and peak infection. This sets the groundwork for an in-depth simulation/analysis phase to produce robust, direct results for reporting.

next_plan: All core static and temporal simulations are now completed. I have generated direct, quantitative static vs. temporal epidemic results for side-by-side comparison, including population trajectories and extracted metrics: epidemic peak size, peak time, final epidemic size, and outbreak duration. The next step is to thoroughly analyze these results in context of the literature, then write and present the full IEEE-style LaTeX report covering the modeling, simulation setup, and outcome analysis, embedding generated figures/tables for clarity. The paper will be completed in the next iteration, drawing from the raw numerical and visual outputs now available.
